Package com.intellij.openapi.editor.impl

Class TextChangesStorage

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intellij.openapi.editor.impl.TextChangesStorage

  • public class TextChangesStorage
extends java.lang.Object
    Allows to store and retrieve TextChange objects assuming that they are applied to the same text.

    Provides ability to automatic merging them if necessary.

    Not thread-safe.

    • Method Detail

      • getChanges

        public java.util.List<TextChangeImpl> getChanges()
        Returns:
        list of changes stored previously via store(TextChange). Note that the changes offsets relate to initial text and that returned list is sorted by start offset in ascending order
        See Also:
        store(TextChange)

      • getChanges

        public java.util.List<? extends TextChange> getChanges(int start,
                                                       int end)
        Allows to ask the storage for the list of changes that have intersections with the target text range (identified by the given arguments).
        Parameters:
        start - target range start offset (inclusive)
        end - target range end offset (exclusive)
        Returns:
        list that contains all registered changes that have intersections with the target text range

      • isEmpty

      • size

        public int size()

      • store

        public void store(TextChange change)
        Store given change merging it with previously stored ones if necessary.

        Note: it's assumed that given change offsets are related to the current state of the text ('client text'), i.e. with all stored changes applied to it. Example:

        1. Say, we have initial text '12345';
        2. Suppose the change 'replace text at [2; 3) range with 'ABC'' is applied to it (stored at the current object). End-users see the text '12ABC45' now;
        3. This method is called with change like 'replace text at [1; 6) range with 'XY''. Change range is assumed to be related to the text visible to end-user, not initial one ('12ABC45', not '12345'). I.e. the user will see text '1XY5' now;
        Parameters:
        change - change to store

      • charAt

        public char charAt(char [] originalData,
                   int index)
        Allows to retrieve character for the given index assuming that it should be resolved against 'client text', i.e. the text contained at the given original char sequence with all registered changes applied to it.

        Example: 

         
          
   
        • Consider that original text is  '01234';
          • 
   
        • 
     Consider that two changes are registered:  'insert text 'a' at index 1' and
      'insert text 'bc' at index 3';
   
          • 
   
        •  'client text' now is  '0a12bc34';
          • 
   
        • This method is called with index '5' - symbol 'c' is returned;
          •
        Parameters:
        originalData - original text to which registered changes are applied
        index - target symbol index (is assumed to be 'client text' index)
        Returns:
        'client text' symbol at the given index

      • substring

        public java.lang.CharSequence substring(char [] originalData,
                                        int start,
                                        int end)
        Allows to build substring of the client text with its changes registered within the current storage.
        Parameters:
        originalData - original text to which registered changes are applied
        start - target substring start offset (against the 'client text'; inclusive)
        end - target substring end offset (against the 'client text'; exclusive)
        Returns:
        substring for the given text range
